awd_titl_txt: FW-HTF-P: Safeguarding the Health of Healthcare Workers During Future Pandemics, Using Robotics and Automation
awd_abstract_narration:
The COVID-19 pandemic has stressed the healthcare system to the breaking point and has transformed healthcare delivery, forcing a strong shift to telemedicine. This reduction in-person healthcare visits is a key strategy for healthcare surge control now and in the future. However, current tele-systems provide mostly communication support, while the physical interactions required for diagnostic procedures, interventional procedures, and bedside care still largely rely on in-person care. Innovative approaches in automation and robotics have the potential to assist and protect healthcare workers in many of these areas of patient care. The current work develops novel compliant actuators to enable safe physical interactions with patients, thus minimizing the need for physical contact with healthcare providers. The investigators will design robotic systems with varying degrees of autonomy, using a vascular access delivery system as a testbed. The technology developed in this project can be used to mitigate the impact of the next pandemic and spearhead change in healthcare for the future. 

This project serves healthcare workers in clinical settings who care for patients with infectious and other diseases by investigating robotics, autonomous systems, trust of physical human-robot interaction and the impacts on safety, productivity, and economics. The proposed research and experiments on compliant robotics should yield new techniques for medical robots that are safe for physical interaction with humans, while maintaining low cost for mass production. The proposed control-design activities address shortfalls in current autonomous robot controllers by providing new strategies to maximize safety, trust, and performance. Finally, this work brings stakeholders from nursing, medicine, economics, and psychology together with experts in medical robotics, artificial intelligence, autonomy, and disease transmission to provide a roadmap for a sustainable future of healthcare in which increased use of robots and autonomous systems is part of the solution.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report: Safeguarding Healthcare Workers During Pandemics Through Robotics and Automation

This NSF Future of Work project investigated how robotics and automation can protect healthcare workers during infectious disease outbreaks like COVID-19, while ensuring these workers can thrive in an increasingly automated healthcare environment. Our research addressed critical challenges that emerged during the pandemic, particularly the spike in infection rates during central venous catheter procedures.

Intellectual Merit

Our research advanced fundamental knowledge in three interconnected areas:

Healthcare Worker-Centric Approach: We established a strong collaboration with Johns Hopkins School of Nursing and conducted comprehensive surveys and interviews with frontline nurses to assess their needs for robotic automation. Through design thinking sessions, we gathered invaluable feedback on robotic prototypes for central venous catheterization. This approach ensured our technological innovations directly addressed clinical needs while considering human factors.

Novel Compliant Actuators: We developed highly integrated direct-drive smart motors with built-in sensors that deliver significant torque (150 mNm) for both translation and rotation of endovascular instruments while maintaining a small footprint. These compliant actuators ensure safe human-robot interaction in clinical settings. Additionally, we created hollow actuators with central openings (Φ12mm) that allow catheters or guidewires to pass through, simplifying mechatronics design and improving procedure efficiency. We also developed pneumatic soft actuators with integrated sensing capabilities for delicate interactions.

Degrees of Autonomy: We implemented a vascular access testbed demonstrating various levels of autonomy, from teleoperation to shared control to supervised autonomy. Our novel bedside admittance controller for a dual-segment soft robot catheter achieved position accuracy of 0.4±0.4mm, significantly outperforming expert cardiologists using standard techniques. We developed deep learning algorithms for vessel detection with a Dice score of 89.21% and created a compact 4-DOF catheter robot that is 90% smaller than existing commercial systems while maintaining clinically relevant capabilities.

Broader Impacts

This project has made significant contributions beyond advancing technical knowledge:

Healthcare Delivery: Our robotic systems have the potential to reduce infection risks during vascular access procedures, a critical need identified during the pandemic. The portable catheter robot we developed enables procedures to be performed with minimal staff present, reducing exposure risks during infectious disease outbreaks.

Workforce Development: The project supported training for PhD students, Master's students, and undergraduate researchers, including members of underrepresented groups in STEM. This multidisciplinary research fostered collaboration between engineering, nursing, and medicine, creating valuable cross-disciplinary training opportunities.

Knowledge Dissemination: Our findings were presented at numerous conferences and seminars, including NSF Future of Work PI meetings, and resulted in multiple peer-reviewed publications. These venues facilitated broader discussions about how robotics and automation can support rather than replace healthcare workers.

Healthcare System Resilience: By developing technologies that can be deployed during infectious disease outbreaks, this research contributes to healthcare system preparedness for future pandemics, potentially reducing healthcare worker infections and improving patient outcomes.

This research demonstrates how thoughtfully designed robotic systems can enhance healthcare delivery while prioritizing the needs and expertise of human workers, providing a model for human-centered automation in critical environments.


Last Modified: 03/18/2025
Modified by: Axel Krieger

Project Outcomes Report: Safeguarding Healthcare Workers During Pandemics Through Robotics and Automation


This NSF Future of Work project investigated how robotics and automation can protect healthcare workers during infectious disease outbreaks like COVID-19, while ensuring these workers can thrive in an increasingly automated healthcare environment. Our research addressed critical challenges that emerged during the pandemic, particularly the spike in infection rates during central venous catheter procedures.


Intellectual Merit


Our research advanced fundamental knowledge in three interconnected areas:


Healthcare Worker-Centric Approach: We established a strong collaboration with Johns Hopkins School of Nursing and conducted comprehensive surveys and interviews with frontline nurses to assess their needs for robotic automation. Through design thinking sessions, we gathered invaluable feedback on robotic prototypes for central venous catheterization. This approach ensured our technological innovations directly addressed clinical needs while considering human factors.


Novel Compliant Actuators: We developed highly integrated direct-drive smart motors with built-in sensors that deliver significant torque (150 mNm) for both translation and rotation of endovascular instruments while maintaining a small footprint. These compliant actuators ensure safe human-robot interaction in clinical settings. Additionally, we created hollow actuators with central openings (12mm) that allow catheters or guidewires to pass through, simplifying mechatronics design and improving procedure efficiency. We also developed pneumatic soft actuators with integrated sensing capabilities for delicate interactions.


Degrees of Autonomy: We implemented a vascular access testbed demonstrating various levels of autonomy, from teleoperation to shared control to supervised autonomy. Our novel bedside admittance controller for a dual-segment soft robot catheter achieved position accuracy of 0.40.4mm, significantly outperforming expert cardiologists using standard techniques. We developed deep learning algorithms for vessel detection with a Dice score of 89.21% and created a compact 4-DOF catheter robot that is 90% smaller than existing commercial systems while maintaining clinically relevant capabilities.


Broader Impacts


This project has made significant contributions beyond advancing technical knowledge:


Healthcare Delivery: Our robotic systems have the potential to reduce infection risks during vascular access procedures, a critical need identified during the pandemic. The portable catheter robot we developed enables procedures to be performed with minimal staff present, reducing exposure risks during infectious disease outbreaks.


Workforce Development: The project supported training for PhD students, Master's students, and undergraduate researchers, including members of underrepresented groups in STEM. This multidisciplinary research fostered collaboration between engineering, nursing, and medicine, creating valuable cross-disciplinary training opportunities.


Knowledge Dissemination: Our findings were presented at numerous conferences and seminars, including NSF Future of Work PI meetings, and resulted in multiple peer-reviewed publications. These venues facilitated broader discussions about how robotics and automation can support rather than replace healthcare workers.


Healthcare System Resilience: By developing technologies that can be deployed during infectious disease outbreaks, this research contributes to healthcare system preparedness for future pandemics, potentially reducing healthcare worker infections and improving patient outcomes.


This research demonstrates how thoughtfully designed robotic systems can enhance healthcare delivery while prioritizing the needs and expertise of human workers, providing a model for human-centered automation in critical environments.					Last Modified: 03/18/2025
